title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don‚Äôt be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: ‚ÄúI fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER‚Äù. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let‚Äôs examine the reasons: (1) ain‚Äôt nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‚Äòyou‚Äô exist is because your dad‚Äôs sperm fertilized your mom‚Äôs egg. Somewhere along the way, ‚Äòyou‚Äô came into existence. However, the answer to the question ‚ÄúWhy did you fall off your bike?‚Äù requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let‚Äôs view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let‚Äôs begin at the moment in which ‚Äúyou‚Äù obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, ‚Äúyou‚Äù are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of ‚Äúyour‚Äù existence (‚Äòconsciousness‚Äô), as well as develop an awareness of ‚Äòthoughts‚Äô and a procedure of thoughts (‚Äòthinking‚Äô), and eventually learn from the environment (‚Äòintelligence‚Äô, ‚Äòcognition‚Äô, or as I like to say, ‚Äòan ability to connect the dots‚Äô). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‚Äòinformation‚Äô) interpreted as truth (‚Äòknowledge‚Äô), which we store in our ‚Äòmemory‚Äô. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (‚Äòunderstanding‚Äô). Putting this all together, ‚Äúwe‚Äù exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (‚Äòexperience‚Äô) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our ‚Äòimagination‚Äô -- the power to ‚Äúsee the unseen‚Äù. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our '‚Äúinterpretation engine‚Äù) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now ‚Ä¶ but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience ‚Ä¶ our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- ‚Äútake nobody‚Äôs word for it‚Äù.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it‚Äôs truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth ‚Ä¶ though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying ‚Äúwisdom of the crowd‚Äù. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying ‚Äúfatality of the mob‚Äù. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, ‚Äúhistory is written by the winners‚Äù, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser‚Äôs side. This is not all the publisher‚Äôs fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism or The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Problem -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular events‚Äô existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase ‚Äúdrawing a conclusion‚Äù. Every piece of evidence or historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaurs‚Äô existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later 'discovers' them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), G√∂del‚Äôs Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science)¬†all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don‚Äôt read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant‚Äôs *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have ‚Äòcreativity‚Äô -- an ability to create new ‚Äúthings‚Äù. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *‚ÄúWhat I cannot create, I do not understand‚Äù*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‚Äòthe seen‚Äô in terms of ‚Äòthe unseen‚Äô. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom‚Äôs nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Why‚Äôs method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *‚ÄúScience is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.‚Äù*
>
> ‚Äî Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be to accurately describe Truth. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‚Äòjustified true belief‚Äô theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (with a capital ‚ÄòT‚Äô). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a ‚Äúlaw‚Äù of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new knowledge debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There are things that we simply do not know about reality.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also fuel predictions -‚Üí which builds knowledge -‚Üí which inspires imagination -‚Üí which creates explanations. These ‚Äòcreations‚Äô bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‚Äòyou‚Äô). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and imagination and is stored in memory. It reveals unknown unknowns. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change in our lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain ‚Ä¶ with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event‚Äôs existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say ‚ÄúI am uncertain‚Äù, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Here‚Äôs a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be ‚ÄòHidden‚Äô variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* ‚Ä¶. so ‚Ä¶ how do you know if the measured response in the ‚Äòeffect variable‚Äô was the result of varying the ‚Äòcause variable‚Äô or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations can generate knowledge from information not apparent in the observations or statistics. An explanation can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium‚Äôs sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty ‚Ä¶ so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that ‚Äúmeaning‚Äù is an important part of the brain‚Äôs interpretation engine. Sooo ‚Ä¶ what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post‚Ä¶

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously ‚Äúexists‚Äù without an agent or precise initial moment. I enjoyed Brett Hall‚Äôs view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. I also enjoyed Evan Conrad‚Äôs article which explains that ‚Äúyou‚Äù are not your ‚Äúthoughts‚Äù. ‚ÄúYou‚Äù observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thought in the sense that you may be aware of a thought and its relation to ‚Äúyou‚Äù (as an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought).

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise.

\*\*\*\*\* In the realm of knowledge, there is no such thing as a law of nature or Truth (with a capital ‚ÄòT‚Äô). There are just REALLY good explanations that may resemble Truth (called theories in science). However, Truth does exist and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital ‚ÄòF‚Äô). Knowledge is thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth).

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zeno‚Äôs Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new ‚Äúthings‚Äù (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. If reality is a function mapping moments to moments, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of function is it? Also, what happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? In logic, a concept of time is unnecessary.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually ‚Äúbe‚Äù a sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*A change in the dependent variable (effect) may be caused by an unaccounted or unknown factor (cause) rather than the independent factor. This may be ‚Äúconfounding'‚Äú to some. Others say Hidden variables, once identified in an experiment, are ‚Äúextraneous‚Äù if they think they can be controlled. It is hard to control variables (especially unknown ones) in experiments, and physical experiments are temporal in nature.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Correlation is an association between sets, not a function. Causality is a function of sorts.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don‚Äôt be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: ‚ÄúI fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER‚Äù. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let‚Äôs examine the reasons: (1) ain‚Äôt nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‚Äòyou‚Äô exist is because your dad‚Äôs sperm fertilized your mom‚Äôs egg. Somewhere along the way, ‚Äòyou‚Äô came into existence. However, the answer to the question ‚ÄúWhy did you fall off your bike?‚Äù requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let‚Äôs view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let‚Äôs begin at the moment in which ‚Äúyou‚Äù obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, ‚Äúyou‚Äù are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of ‚Äúyour‚Äù existence (‚Äòconsciousness‚Äô), as well as develop an awareness of ‚Äòthoughts‚Äô and a procedure of thoughts (‚Äòthinking‚Äô), and eventually learn from the environment (‚Äòintelligence‚Äô, ‚Äòcognition‚Äô, or as I like to say, ‚Äòan ability to connect the dots‚Äô). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‚Äòinformation‚Äô) interpreted as truth (‚Äòknowledge‚Äô), which we store in our ‚Äòmemory‚Äô. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (‚Äòunderstanding‚Äô). Putting this all together, ‚Äúwe‚Äù exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (‚Äòexperience‚Äô) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our ‚Äòimagination‚Äô -- the power to ‚Äúsee the unseen‚Äù. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our '‚Äúinterpretation engine‚Äù) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now ‚Ä¶ but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience ‚Ä¶ our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- ‚Äútake nobody‚Äôs word for it‚Äù.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it‚Äôs truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth ‚Ä¶ though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying ‚Äúwisdom of the crowd‚Äù. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying ‚Äúfatality of the mob‚Äù. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, ‚Äúhistory is written by the winners‚Äù, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser‚Äôs side. This is not all the publisher‚Äôs fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism or The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Problem -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular events‚Äô existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase ‚Äúdrawing a conclusion‚Äù. Every piece of evidence or historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaurs‚Äô existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later 'discovers' them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), G√∂del‚Äôs Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science)¬†all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don‚Äôt read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant‚Äôs *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have ‚Äòcreativity‚Äô -- an ability to create new ‚Äúthings‚Äù. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *‚ÄúWhat I cannot create, I do not understand‚Äù*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‚Äòthe seen‚Äô in terms of ‚Äòthe unseen‚Äô. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom‚Äôs nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Why‚Äôs method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *‚ÄúScience is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.‚Äù*
>
> ‚Äî Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be to accurately describe Truth. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‚Äòjustified true belief‚Äô theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (with a capital ‚ÄòT‚Äô). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a ‚Äúlaw‚Äù of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new knowledge debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There are things that we simply do not know about reality.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also fuel predictions -‚Üí which builds knowledge -‚Üí which inspires imagination -‚Üí which creates explanations. These ‚Äòcreations‚Äô bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‚Äòyou‚Äô). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and imagination and is stored in memory. It reveals unknown unknowns. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change in our lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain ‚Ä¶ with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event‚Äôs existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say ‚ÄúI am uncertain‚Äù, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Here‚Äôs a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be ‚ÄòHidden‚Äô variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* ‚Ä¶. so ‚Ä¶ how do you know if the measured response in the ‚Äòeffect variable‚Äô was the result of varying the ‚Äòcause variable‚Äô or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations can generate knowledge from information not apparent in the observations or statistics. An explanation can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium‚Äôs sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty ‚Ä¶ so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that ‚Äúmeaning‚Äù is an important part of the brain‚Äôs interpretation engine. Sooo ‚Ä¶ what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post‚Ä¶

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously ‚Äúexists‚Äù without an agent or precise initial moment. I enjoyed Brett Hall‚Äôs view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. I also enjoyed Evan Conrad‚Äôs article which explains that ‚Äúyou‚Äù are not your ‚Äúthoughts‚Äù. ‚ÄúYou‚Äù observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thought in the sense that you may be aware of a thought and its relation to ‚Äúyou‚Äù (as an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought).

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise.

\*\*\*\*\* In the realm of knowledge, there is no such thing as a law of nature or Truth (with a capital ‚ÄòT‚Äô). There are just REALLY good explanations that may resemble Truth (called theories in science). However, Truth does exist and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital ‚ÄòF‚Äô). Knowledge is thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth).

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zeno‚Äôs Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new ‚Äúthings‚Äù (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. If reality is a function mapping moments to moments, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of function is it? Also, what happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? In logic, a concept of time is unnecessary.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually ‚Äúbe‚Äù a sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*A change in the dependent variable (effect) may be caused by an unaccounted or unknown factor (cause) rather than the independent factor. This may be ‚Äúconfounding'‚Äú to some. Others say Hidden variables, once identified in an experiment, are ‚Äúextraneous‚Äù if they think they can be controlled. It is hard to control variables (especially unknown ones) in experiments, and physical experiments are temporal in nature.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Correlation is an association between sets, not a function. Causality is a function of sorts.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

Êú¨ÊñáÁ∫Ø‰∏™‰∫∫ÊÄùËÄÉÂèäÂàÜ‰∫´Ôºå‰∏çÊûÑÊàê‰ªª‰ΩïÊåáÂØºÊÄßÂª∫ËÆÆÔºåÊ¨¢ËøéÂÖ±Âêå‰∫§ÊµÅÊé¢ËÆ®„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÊàë‰πãÂâçÂÜôÁöÑÊñáÁ´†Âá†‰πéÂÖ®ÈÉ®ÈÉΩÊòØÊäÄÊúØÂàÜ‰∫´Á±ªÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ËøôÁ±ªÊñáÁ´†Á≠îÊ°àÊòéÁ°ÆÔºåÁªìÊûúÊ∏ÖÊô∞„ÄÇÂπ≥Êó∂ÂæàÂ∞ëÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∫õÂΩ¢ËÄå‰∏äÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ËøôÁ±ªÊñáÁ´†ÊúâÂ§ßÈáè‰∏™‰∫∫ËßÜËßí‰∏ãÁöÑ‰∏ªËßÇÁúãÊ≥ïÔºåÊ≤°ÊúâÂÆåÂÖ®ÁöÑÂØπÈîô‰πãÂàÜÔºå‰ΩøÂæóÂæàÂÆπÊòì‰∫ßÁîüÁ¢∞ÊíûÔºå‰∏îÊàë‰πüÊ≤°ÂäûÊ≥ï‰øùËØÅÊàëËØ¥ÁöÑÊòØÂØπÁöÑÔºåÈöèÁùÄËÆ§Áü•Ëø≠‰ª£Ê≠£Â¶ÇÊàëÂõûÈ°æÂá†‰∏™ÊúàÂâçÁöÑÊÉ≥Ê≥ï‰ºöËßâÂæóÈùûÂ∏∏ÂπºÁ®öÔºåËøôÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÊòØÊàëÂ∞ÜËøëÊúü‰∏éÂêÑ‰Ωç‰∫§ÊµÅÂíåÊÄùËÄÉÁöÑ‰∏§ÁØáÂ∞èÁü≠ÊñáÁöÑÊï¥ÂêàÔºåÂ∏åÊúõÂàÜ‰∫´ÁªôÂêÑ‰ΩçËÉΩÂ§üÊúâÊâÄÂêØÂèë„ÄÇ

**Â∞èÁü≠Êñá‰∏ÄÔºöweb3Áªô‰∫àÊôÆÈÄö‰∫∫ÁöÑÂõûÊä•ÂêéÁΩÆÊÄß**

‰ªäÂ§©ÂíåÂ∞è‰ºô‰º¥ËÅädao‰ª•Âèäweb3ÂõûÊä•ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåWeb3‰Ωú‰∏∫ÊôÆÈÄö‰∫∫ÁöÑÈ≠ÖÂäõÂú®‰∫éÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂõûÊä•ÁöÑÊÉäÂñúÊÑüÊòØÊûÅÂÖ∂Âº∫ÁöÑÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Èìæ‰∏äÊï∞ÊçÆ‰ΩøÂæó‰Ω†ÊâÄÂèÇÂä†Âíå‰ªòÂá∫ÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÈÉΩ‰ºöÂú®‰∏çÁü•‰∏çËßâ‰∏≠Ë¢´ÈªòÈªòÁöÑËÆ∞ÂΩï‰∫Ü‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÂΩìËøô‰∏™È°πÁõÆÂà∞‰∫ÜÂèëtokenÁöÑÈò∂ÊÆµÊó∂Ôºå‰æø‰ºöÊ†πÊçÆ‰Ω†ÁöÑËÆ∞ÂΩïÁªô‰∫à‰∏ÄÂÆöÊï∞È¢ùÁöÑÂõûÊä•ÔºåÂç≥Á©∫ÊäïÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫web3È°πÁõÆÊúâ80%ÁîöËá≥‰ª•‰∏äÁöÑtoken‰ªΩÈ¢ùÊòØÁªôÂà∞ÈùûÂõ¢Èòü‰ª•Â§ñÁöÑ‰∫∫Áæ§ÔºåËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÁ¨îÊûÅÂÖ∂Â§ßÁöÑË¥¢ÂØåÂàÜÈÖç‰∏éËΩ¨ÁßªÔºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÂÅöÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÊâæÂà∞ÈÇ£‰∫õ‰Ω†ËÆ§‰∏∫ÊúâÊΩúÂäõÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÔºåÂèÇ‰∏éËøõÂéªÔºåÈùôÈùôÁöÑÁ≠âÂæÖÂÆÉÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊüêÂ§©Â∏¶Áªô‰Ω†ÁöÑÂõûÊä•„ÄÇ

Êàë‰∏æÊàëËá™Â∑±ÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êÔºåÊàëÂú®‰∏ÄÂºÄÂßãÂÜôÊñáÁ´†ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂæà‰∏çÊÑøÊÑèÂèëÂú®mirrorÔºåÈÇ£Êó∂ÂÄôÊÑüËßâÊ≤°‰ªÄ‰πàÁî®ÔºåÂèà‰∏çÁªôÊàëÊµÅÈáèÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂèëÂÖ¨‰ºóÂè∑Ê≤°ÂáÜËøòËÉΩËµöÁÇπÊâìËµèÔºåÊúâÊúãÂèãÂëäËØâÊàëmirrorÊòØÊúÄcryptoÁöÑ‰∫ßÂìÅÔºåÂª∫ËÆÆÊàë‰πüÂêåÊ≠•Âèë‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºå‰∫éÊòØÊàëÂ∞±ÂÅ∂Â∞îÊääÊñáÁ´†‰πüÊê¨Ëøê‰∏äÂéªÔºåÁ™ÅÁÑ∂Êúâ‰∏ÄÂ§©mirrorËÅîÁ≥ªÂà∞ÊàëËØ¥ÁªèËøáËØÑÈÄâÊàëÁöÑÊñáÁ´†ÂÖ•Âõ¥‰∫Ümirror spotlightÔºåÁªô‰∫ÜÊàë‰∏ÄÊûö$Write tokenÔºåÊàëÊêú‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏ãÂ±ÖÁÑ∂Ë¶Å15‰∏™‰ª•Â§™ÊâçÂèØ‰ª•ÂÖëÊç¢1‰∏™ÔºåÈÇ£Êó∂ÂÄôÁöÑ‰ª∑Ê†ºÂ∞±ÊòØ30Â§ö‰∏á‰∏ÄËæÜÁâπÊñØÊãâ‰∫ÜÔºåÂè™ÊòØÂÜô‰∫ÜÂá†ÁØáÊñáÁ´†Â∞±ÁªôÊàëÁ©∫Êäï‰∫Ü‰∏ÄËæÜËΩ¶ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂ¶ÇÊûúÊäätokenÁáÉÁÉß‰∫ÜÂèØ‰ª•ÂÜçÊç¢‰∏Ä‰∏™mirrorÂüüÂêçÂπ∂Êàê‰∏∫dao memberÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÊàëÁöÑÈÄâÊã©ÊòØÂçñ‰∫ÜÊç¢ËæÜËΩ¶ÔºåËøòÊòØ‰∏ÄÊääÁÅ´ÁÉß‰∫ÜÁâπÊñØÊãâÊç¢‰∏Ä‰∏™Ë∫´‰ªΩÔºåÊ≤°ÊúâÁäπË±´Áõ¥Êé•ÁÉßÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Âà∞‰∫ÜËøô‰∏ÄÊ≠•Â∑≤Áªè‰Ωì‰ºöÂà∞‰∫Üweb3ÁöÑÈ≠ÖÂäõÔºåÂÜôÂá†ÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÈÉΩËÉΩÁªôÊàëÁ©∫Êäï‰∏ÄËæÜËΩ¶ÔºåÈÇ£ÊàëÊääËΩ¶ÁÉß‰∫Ü‰ª•Âêé‰∏çÂæóÁªôÊàëÂ•óÊàø‰∫ÜÂìàÂìàÔºü

ÊàëÂë®Âõ¥ËøòÊúâÂæàÂ§ö‰æãÂ≠êÔºåÊúâÂ∏ÆÂøôÁºñËæëensÁõÆÂΩïÁöÑË¢´Á©∫Êäï‰∏ÄÂ§ßÁ¨îtokenÁöÑÔºåÊúâÂ∏ÆÂøôÁøªËØëÁöÑË¢´Á©∫ÊäïÁöÑÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâÁªèÂéÜËøáËøôÊ†∑‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰ΩìÈ™åÔºå‰ºöÁêÜÊâÄÂ∫îÂΩìÁöÑËÆ§‰∏∫ËøôÂ∞±ÊòØÈ™óÂ≠êÔºåÂè™ÊúâÁªèÂéÜ‰∫ÜÊâçÊòéÁôΩÂéüÊù•ËøòÂèØ‰ª•Ëøô‰πàÁé©„ÄÇ

ËøòÊòØÈÇ£‰∏™ÈÅìÁêÜÔºåweb3È°πÁõÆ80%ÈÉΩ‰ºöÁªôÂà∞Âõ¢Èòü‰ª•Â§ñÔºåËøô‰πàÂ§ßÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁ¨îË¥¢ÂØåÔºåÂè™Ë¶Å‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§üÂú®È°πÁõÆ‰∏≠Áïô‰∏ãËá™Â∑±ÁöÑpowÔºåÂ∞±‰ºöÁªô‰Ω†Á©∫Êäï‰∏ÄÂÆöÊØî‰æãÔºåËÄå‰º†Áªü‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÂ§ßÂ§¥ÂÖ®Ë¢´Âõ¢ÈòüÂíåËµÑÊú¨ÊãøËµ∞‰∫ÜÔºåÊÄé‰πàÂèØËÉΩÂàÜÈÖçÁªôÈÇ£‰∫õÂØπÈ°πÁõÆÊúâË¥°ÁåÆÁöÑÊôÆÈÄö‰∫∫Âë¢Ôºü

ËøôÈáåÊàëÊÉ≥Ë°®ËææÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂú®web3Ëé∑ÂæóÂõûÊä•ÁöÑÊñπÂºèÂ≠òÂú®‰∏§ÁßçÔºàÂΩìÁÑ∂‰∏çÂè™ÊúâËøô‰∏§ÁßçÔºâÔºö

1\.Á°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÁöÑÂ∞è/‰∏≠Èí±ÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÊí∏ÁæäÊØõÔºå‰π∞ÁÇπnftÊêûÊêûÊäïËµÑ‰πãÁ±ªÁöÑÔºåÊàñËÄÖÊòØÂèÇÂä†‰∏Ä‰∏™È°πÁõÆÈ¢ÜÂèñÂÖºËÅåÂ∑•ËµÑ

2\.‰∏çÁ°ÆÂÆöÁöÑ‰∏≠/Â§ßÈí±ÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÈÄâÊã©‰∏Ä‰∏™‰Ω†ËßâÂæóÊúâÊΩúÂäõÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÔºåÂèÇ‰∏éËøõÂéªÔºåÁ≠âÂæÖÂÆÉÁªôÂà∞‰Ω†ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂõûÊä•

‰ª•‰∏ä‰ªÖ‰∏™‰∫∫ËßÅËß£‰∏éÁªèÂéÜÂàÜ‰∫´ÔºåÁÜäÂ∏Ç‰∫ÜÔºåËøôÁßçÊó∂ÂÄôÂêÑ‰∏™È°πÁõÆÈÉΩÊ¥ªÁöÑÊØîËæÉÈöæÊΩÆÊ∞¥Ë§™ÂéªË£∏Ê≥≥ÁöÑË¢´Ê∑òÊ±∞ÂêéÔºåÊ≠£ÊòØ‰Ω†ÂéªÊåëÈÄâÂ•ΩÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåËøôÊó∂ÂÄôÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÂèÇ‰∏éÂà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâÊΩúÂäõÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆ‰∏≠ÔºåÁâõÂ∏ÇÊù•‰∫ÜÂÆÉÂèëtokenÔºåÊàëÁõ∏‰ø°‰Ω†‰ºöÊúâÂ∫îÂæóÁöÑÂõûÊä•

**Â∞èÁü≠Êñá‰∫åÔºöWeb3ÁöÑÂãüËµÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊîπÂèò‰∫ÜÁªÑÁªáÂΩ¢Âºè**

Êú¨ÊñáÂü∫‰∫éÊò®Êó•‰∏é‰∏Ä‰ΩçÊúãÂèãÁöÑ‰∫§ÊµÅÁ¢∞ÊíûÁöÑÂØπË∞àÊâÄÊï¥ÁêÜÊ≤âÊ∑ÄÔºå‰ªéË¥≠‰π∞NFTËÅäÂà∞‰∫ÜDAOÁöÑÁªÑÁªáÁîü‰∫ß„ÄÇ

ËØùÈ¢òËµ∑Âõ†Âú®‰∫éËÄÅÁîüÂ∏∏Ë∞àÁöÑ‚Äú‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà‰∫∫‰ª¨ÊÑøÊÑèËä±Èí±Ë¥≠‰π∞‰∏ÄÂº†ÂõæÁâáÔºü‚ÄùÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êù•ËßÇÂØü‰∏Ä‰∏™Áé∞Ë±°ÔºåÂá†‰πéÊâÄÊúâÁöÑNFTÈÉΩ‰ºöÂú®ÂÆòÁΩëÊîæ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊ®°ÂùóroadmapÊù•ÊèèËø∞È°πÁõÆÊñπÊé•‰∏ãÊù•‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÈÉΩË¶ÅÂÅö‰ªÄ‰πàÔºå‰ªéËÄåËÆ∏ËØ∫Áªô‰Ω†ËøôÊ†∑‰∏Ä‰∏™Êó©ÊúüÊîØÊåÅËÄÖ‰∏Ä‰∫õÊùÉÁõäÔºàÊàñËÄÖËØ¥ÁîªÈ•ºÔºâÔºå‰∫∫‰ª¨‰π∞ÁöÑ‰∏çÊòØËøôÂº†ÂõæÁâáÔºåËÄåÊòØÂõæÁâáËÉåÂêéÈ°πÁõÆÊñπÁªô‰∫àÁöÑÊúüÂæÖÂíåÂØπÊú™Êù•ÁöÑÊÉ≥Ë±°ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰ªéËøô‰∏™ËßíÂ∫¶ÔºåNFTÁöÑÊÄßË¥®Ë∂ãÂêë‰∫éÂãüËµÑ‰ºóÁ≠π„ÄÇ

ÊâÄ‰ª•È°πÁõÆÊñπÂÖàÊäµÊäº„ÄÅÈÄèÊîØ‰∫ÜËá™Â∑±ÁöÑ‰ø°Ë™âÔºåÈÄöËøáÂèëË°åNFT‰ª•Êõ¥‰ΩéÈó®ÊßõÁöÑÂéªÂãüËµÑÂÆåÊàê‰∏Ä‰ª∂‰∫ãÔºåËÄåËøô‰ª∂‰∫ãÈúÄË¶ÅËææÊàêÂº∫Â§ßÁöÑÂÖ±ËØÜÔºåËÆ©Â§ßÂÆ∂ËßâÂæóËøô‰∏™‰∫ãÈùûÂ∏∏ÁöÑÊúâ‰ª∑ÂÄºÊÑè‰πâÔºåÊâçÂèØ‰ª•Âê∏Âºï‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂéªËä±Âá∫ÁúüÈáëÁôΩÈì∂ÂÜíÁùÄÈ£éÈô©Âéª‚ÄúÊäïËµÑ‚Äù„ÄÇ

Ëøô‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàrugÂú®web3È¢ÜÂüü‰ºöËøô‰πà‰∏•ÈáçÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂΩìÂèëË°åÂÆåÊØïÂêéËøô‰πàÂ§ßÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁ¨îËµÑÈáëÁïôÂú®Èí±ÂåÖ‰∏≠ÔºåÊòØÂê¶ËøòÊúâÂÆöÂäõÂèØ‰ª•‰∏çÂøòÂàùÂøÉÂùöÊåÅÊää‰∫ãÊÉÖÂÅöÂÆåÔºåËøôÂ∞±ËÄÉÈ™å‰∫∫ÊÄß‰∫ÜÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•rugËøáÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÊñπ‰ºöÊàê‰∏∫ËøáË°óËÄÅÈº†ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰∏äÊñáËØ¥Âà∞ÂèëË°åNFTÂãüËµÑÁöÑË°å‰∏∫ÊòØÊäµÊäº‰∫ÜËá™Â∑±ÁöÑ‰ø°Ë™âÔºåË¥≠‰π∞ËÄÖÊòØÂÆåÂÖ®Âº±ÂäøÁæ§‰ΩìÂè™ËÉΩÁ•àÁ•∑È°πÁõÆÊñπÁúüÁöÑ‰ºöÂéªÂÅö‰∫ãÔºå‰∏ÄÊó¶rugËøá‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÔºåÊäµÊäºÁöÑ‰ø°Ë™âÁ†¥‰∫ßÔºåÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÂæàÈöæÂÜç‰ø°‰ªªÁ¨¨‰∫åÊ¨°„ÄÇ

ÈÇ£‰πàÂÜçÂæÄ‰∏ãÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∏∏ËØ¥Âàõ‰∏öËÄÖË¶ÅÊâæ‰∫∫ÊâæÈí±ÊâæÊñπÂêëÔºåÈÇ£ÊñπÂêëÂ∞±ÊòØroadmapÔºåÈí±ÂàôÊòØÂèëË°åNFTÔºåÈÇ£‰∫∫Âë¢ÔºüËá™ÁÑ∂‰πüÊòØÂ§üÂçñNFTËÄÖÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Â§ßÂÆ∂ÈÉΩÊòØÂü∫‰∫éroadmapÊâÄËÅöÂú®‰∏ÄËµ∑ÁöÑÔºåËøô‰ª∂‰∫ãÂÅöÊàêÂàô‰ºöËÆ©ÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÊåÅÊúâÁöÑNFTÂÄºÈí±Ôºå‰∫éÊòØ‰ºöÈ©±‰ΩøÂ§ßÂÆ∂Ëá™ÂèëÁöÑÂéª‰∏∫È°πÁõÆÂÅö‰∫ãÔºåÁõ∏ÂΩì‰∫éÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÈÉΩÊòØcofounderÔºåÈÉΩÊòØËÇ°‰∏ú„ÄÇ

body:
ENSÊúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÁî®ÔºüÂú®ËΩ¨Ë¥¶Êó∂Áî®ENSÂêçÂ≠ó‰ª£Êõø‰ª•Â§™ÂùäÂú∞ÂùÄ‰ºº‰πéÊòØÂÖ∂‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÈöèÁùÄË∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ§öÁöÑWeb3Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÂá∫Áé∞ÔºåENSÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®Âú∫ÊôØÂèØËÉΩÂπ∂‰∏çÊòØÈí±ÂåÖÔºåËÄåÊòØÂú®ÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠„ÄÇÊØîÂ¶ÇÂú®MIRROR‰∏≠ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊúâENSÂêçÂ≠óÂπ∂‰∏îÊääÂÆÉ‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂΩìÂâçÂú∞ÂùÄÁöÑ‰∏ªË¶ÅENSÂêçÂ≠óÔºå‰Ω†Â∞ÜËá™Âä®Ëé∑Âæó‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∏¶ENSÂêçÂ≠óÁöÑMIRRORËøûÊé•ÔºåÂê¶ÂàôÂ∞ÜÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏çÂèØË®ÄËØ¥ÁöÑHASHÂú∞ÂùÄ„ÄÇ

ENSÂêçÂ≠óÊ≠£Âú®Ë¢´Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ§öÁöÑÁ§æ‰∫§Â∫îÁî®‰ΩøÁî®ÔºåÂÖ∂ÂäüËÉΩÁõ∏ÂΩì‰∫éWeb 2Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑Âêç„ÄÇLENSÁöÑÂá∫Áé∞Â∞±Ë∑üÈí±ÂåÖÂíåËΩ¨Ë¥¶Ê≤°ÊúâÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºåÂÆÉÂÆåÂÖ®ÊòØ‰∏∫Á§æ‰∫§ËÄåÁîüÁöÑ„ÄÇÂú®LensÂçèËÆÆ‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™ProfileÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰ª•.lensÁªìÂ∞æhandleÔºåÂΩ¢Âºè‰∏ä‰∏éENSÁöÑÂüüÂêçÊó†ÂºÇ„ÄÇÁõÆÂâçÁî±‰∫éProfileÁöÑÁî≥ËØ∑ÔºàÊ≥®ÂÜåÔºâÊòØÈúÄË¶ÅÁôΩÂêçÂçïÁöÑÔºå.lensÁöÑÂêçÂ≠óÁé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•ËØ¥ÊòØ‰∏ÄÁ•®ÈöæÊ±Ç„ÄÇLensÂõ¢ÈòüÊ≠£ÊòØÈÄöËøáËøôÁßçÁôΩÂêçÂçïÁöÑÊéßÂà∂Ê≥®ÂÜåÊñπÂºèÂΩ¢Êàê.lensÁöÑÁ®ÄÁº∫ÊÄßÔºåÂπ∂‰ª•Ê≠§‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏ÄÁßçÁ§æÂå∫Á¶èÂà©‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ§æÂå∫ËøõË°åÂêà‰ΩúÔºå‰æùÈù†ÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ§æÂå∫ÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄÊù•Êé®ÂπøLensÔºåÁîöËá≥ËøûENSÁöÑNickÈÉΩÂøç‰∏ç‰ΩèË¶Å‰∏∫ENSÁöÑÁî®Êà∑‰∫âÂèñLensÁöÑÁôΩÂêçÂçïÊùÉÂà©„ÄÇ

LENSËôΩÁÑ∂‰ª•Á§æ‰∫§ÂõæË∞±ÁöÑË∫´‰ªΩÂá∫Áé∞ÔºåÁªô‰∫∫ÁöÑÁõ¥ËßÇÊÑüËßâÂç¥ÊòØÂè¶Â§ñÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂüüÂêçÁ≥ªÁªüÔºåÂú®ÂÖ∂ÁîüÊÄÅÂ∫îÁî®Ê≤°ÊúâËµ∑Êù•‰ª•ÂâçÔºåËé∑Âèñ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â•ΩÁöÑÂêçÂ≠óÊú¨Ë∫´ÊòØ‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÁÇπ„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØ‰ªéENSÂà∞LENSÔºå‰∏ÄÂ≠ó‰πãÂ∑ÆÔºåËÉåÂêéÁöÑÈúÄÊ±ÇÂ∑≤ÁªèÊÇÑÊÇÑÂú∞ÂèëÁîü‰∫ÜÂèòÂåñÔºåLENSÁöÑÊΩúÂäõÂíåÂäüËÉΩ‰πãÂº∫Â§ß‰πü‰ª§‰∫∫ÊÉäÂèπÔºåÂÆÉ‰∏ç‰ªÖÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêçÂ≠óÔºå‰Ω†ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÂÆÉÊù•ÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∏™TwitterÊàñËÄÖÊúãÂèãÂúàËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁ§æ‰∫§Â™í‰ΩìËΩØ‰ª∂„ÄÇTwitterÁîöËá≥Facebook‰πüËÆ∏ÈÉΩÊÑüÂèóÂà∞‰∫ÜÊù•ËÄÖ‰∏çÂñÑ„ÄÅ‰∫öÂéÜÂ±±Â§ßÔºå‰∏çÁü•ÈÅì‰ªÖÂ§ö‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÊØçÁöÑLENSÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâËÆ©ENSÊÑüÂà∞ÂéãÂäõÔºü

beagle.chatÂºÄÂßãÂÖ≥Ê≥®ENS‰πüÊòØÂ∏åÊúõÁî®ÂÆÉÊù•ÂÅöËøô‰∏™‰ºöËÆÆÂíåËÅäÂ§©ËΩØ‰ª∂ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂêçÔºåÂØπ‰∫éÊ≤°ÊúâENSÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÂÖçË¥πÁî≥ËØ∑‰∏Ä‰∏™.beagles.ethÁöÑÂ≠êÂüüÂêçÔºåÊØîÂ¶Çsnoopy.beagles.eth„ÄÇÁî±‰∫éGASÂ§™È´òÊàë‰ª¨ÂºÄÂßãÁ†îÁ©∂ENSÁöÑLayer 2Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºåÂ∏åÊúõÂú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆÉÁöÑÈìæ‰∏äÂÆûÁé∞Â≠êÂüüÂêçÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÔºåÁî±Ê≠§‰∫ßÁîü‰∫ÜDNS3Ëøô‰∏™È°πÁõÆ„ÄÇENSÁöÑSDKÁõÆÂâçÊòØÊúÄÂèãÂ•ΩÂíåÂÆåÂñÑÁöÑÂüüÂêçÂºÄÂèëÂåÖÔºåÂç≥‰ΩøÈõÜÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁßÅÊúâÈÉ®ÁΩ≤ÁöÑENSÂêàÁ∫¶ÔºåÂÖ∂Â≠¶‰π†‰ª£‰ª∑ÂíåÈ£éÈô©‰πüËøúËøú‰Ωé‰∫éÈõÜÊàêÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑDID„ÄÇ

‰∏∫‰∫ÜÁî®Á®≥Â¶•„ÄÅÁúÅÈí±ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊãøÂà∞Â••Âæ∑ËµõÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂë®ÁöÑ‰∏§‰∏™NFTÔºåÊàëÁ≠â‰∫ÜË∂≥Ë∂≥ÂõõÂ§©ÔºåËøáÊª§‰∫ÜËÆ∏Â§öÂûÉÂúæ‰ø°ÊÅØÂêéÔºå‰∏∫Â§ßÂÆ∂ÂÅöÂá∫‰∫ÜÊú¨Ê¨°ÊîªÁï•„ÄÇ

ÁõÆÂâçÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂêÑÁßçÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∑≤ÁªèÂü∫Êú¨ÊàêÂûãÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâÁâπÊÆäÊÉÖÂÜµÔºåÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÂºÄÂßãÊääËá™Â∑±ÁöÑË∑®Èìæ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

### È¶ñÂÖàÊàë‰ª¨ÂÖàÊù•‰∫ÜËß£Âá†‰∏™ÂÖ≥ÈîÆ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºö

**1.Â••Âæ∑ËµõÂè™Êé•ÂèóETHÂÖ•ÈìæÔºå‰πü‰∏çË¶ÅÁ≠âÂà∞ÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÂ§©ÂÜçË∑®ÈìæÔºåÂç°Âì≠‰∫ÜÂà´ÊÄ™‰ªª‰Ωï‰∫∫**„ÄÇÂú®‰∏ãÂë®‰∫å‰πãÂâçÂ∞ÜETHË∑®ÈìæÂà∞arbÈìæ‰∏ä‰πãÂêéÂ∞Ü‰ºöËé∑ÂæóÂ••Âæ∑ËµõË∑®ÈìæÂë®ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™NFTÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ¥ªÂä®ÁªìÊùüÂêéÔºå‰Ω†‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑË∑®ÈìæÊ°•ÊòØ‰º†ÈÄÅETHÊúÄÂ§öÁöÑÈÇ£‰∏Ä‰∏™ÔºåËøòËÉΩÈ¢ùÂ§ñËé∑Âæó‰∏Ä‰∏™NFT„ÄÇÂæàÂ§ö‰∫∫ÈÉΩÂú®Á≠âÂæÖÊúÄÂêéÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂæàÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊúÄÂêé‰∏§Â§©‰ºöÂæàÂç°ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÊúÄÂ•ΩÊèêÂâçÂá†Â§©ÂÆåÊàê‰Ω†Â§ßÂ§öÊï∞Èí±ÂåÖÁöÑË∑®Èìæ‰ªªÂä°Ôºå

**2.ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®bungeeÁöÑÂêåÊó∂ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®hopÔºåÂÆåÊàê‰∏§‰∏™Ê°•ÁöÑË∑®Èìæ**„ÄÇÁõÆÂâçETHËΩ¨ÁßªÈáèÊúÄÂ§ßÁöÑÊ°•ÂàÜÂà´ÊòØHopÂíåBungeeÔºàÂç≥SocketÔºâÔºåËÄåBungeeÊú¨Ë∫´ÈõÜÊàê‰∫ÜhopÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÁâπÂà´‰ΩøÁî®HopË∑®Èìæ„ÄÇ

![nansenÁöÑÈìæ‰∏äÂàÜÊûêÊúÄ‰∏∫ÂáÜÁ°ÆÔºåÂÖ∂‰ªñÂàÜÊûêÂ§öÊúâÂÅèÂ∑ÆÔºåÂèØÁï•Ëøá‰∏çÁúã](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/9VNwenU913fT3ViDSROaK.png?height=471&width=664)

**3.ÊúÄÂ•Ω‰∏çË¶ÅÊèêÂ∏ÅÂà∞polygonË∑®Èìæ**ÔºåÁõÆÂâçÂ∑≤ÁªèÊúâ‰∫∫ÁõëÊéß‰∫ÜÂêÑ‰∏™‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÈí±ÂåÖÔºåÂè™Ë¶ÅÊúâ‰ªé‰∫§ÊòìÊâÄÊèêÂ∏ÅÂá∫Êù•ÁöÑÔºåÂ∞±‰ºöÊâìÂÖ•0.00001‰∏™maticÔºåËÆ©‰Ω†Ë¢´Âä®ÂèòÊàêÂ•≥Â∑´ÔºåÂêåÊó∂polygon‰∏äÁöÑethÂ∑≤ÁªèÊé•ËøõÊûØÁ´≠ÔºåÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöË∑®‰∏ç‰∫ÜÈìæ

**4.imTokenÈí±ÂåÖ‰πüÂú®Êú¨Âë®ÂºÄÂßã‰∫ÜIliadÔºà‰ºäÂà©‰∫öÁâπÔºâÊ¥ªÂä®**„ÄÇÂá°ÊòØ‰ΩøÁî®imTokenÂÆåÊàêÂ••Âæ∑ËµõÊ¥ªÂä®ÁöÑÂú∞ÂùÄÔºåÈÉΩ‰ºöÈ¢ùÂ§ñËé∑ÂæóimTokenËµ†ÈÄÅÁöÑNFT„ÄÇ

ÊúÄÂêéÂÜçÁªìÂêà‰πãÂâçÂÜôËøáÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁØáÂÖ≥‰∫éweb3Ë¥¢ÂØåÂÜçÂàÜÈÖçÊ∑±Êåñ‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåÊàë‰ªé10Â≤ÅÊã•Êúâ‰∫ÜÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™QQÂè∑ÔºåÈô™‰º¥ÁùÄËÖæËÆØ‰ªéÂ∞èÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëµ∞Âà∞‰∫ÜÂçÉ‰∫øÂ∏ÇÂÄºÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØËÖæËÆØÁöÑÊàêÂäüÂíåÊàëÊúâÂÖ≥Á≥ªÂêóÔºüËÖæËÆØÂÆåÊàê‰∏äÂ∏ÇÂêéÊàëË¥≠‰π∞ÂÆÉÁöÑËÇ°Á•®‰πüÂè™ËÉΩÂÆûÁé∞Ë¥¢Âä°ÊäïËµÑÂõûÊä•ÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏ËøêËΩ¨ÂÜ≥Á≠ñÊàë‰πü‰∏çËÉΩÂèÇ‰∏éÂÖ∂‰∏≠„ÄÇ

‰ΩÜÊòØËøôÂêàÁêÜÂêóÔºüÈùûÂ∏∏ÂêàÁêÜÔºåËÖæËÆØËâ∞Ëã¶Âàõ‰∏öÁº∫Èí±Áº∫‰∫∫ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÊàëÂú®Âì™ÔºåÊàëÊó¢ÁÑ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÈô™ÂÆÉÂÖ±Ëã¶ÔºåËá™ÁÑ∂‰πü‰∏çÂ∫îËØ•ÂêåÁîòÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂæàÂ§ö‰∫∫‰ºöÂØπÁé∞Âú®ÁöÑÂïÜ‰∏öÊ®°ÂºèÊÑ§ÊÑ§‰∏çÂπ≥ÔºåËßâÂæóËøô‰∫õÂ∑®Â§¥‰∏çÁªôÂàÜÂà©Ê∂¶ÊòØ‰∏çÂØπÁöÑÔºåÊàë‰Ωú‰∏∫Áî®Êà∑‰∏çÂèÇ‰∏éÂÜ≥Á≠ñÊòØ‰∏çÂØπÁöÑÔºåÊ≤°Âï•‰∏çÂØπÁöÑÔºå‰∫∫ÂÆ∂Êú¨Ë∫´Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÑöÂç∞ÊâçÊääÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂÅöÊàêÔºåÈÇ£‰∫õÊó©ÊúüÂèÇ‰∏éËøõÂàõ‰∏öÁöÑÂëòÂ∑•„ÄÅÊó©ÊúüÂÜíÁùÄÈ£éÈô©ÊäïËµÑÁöÑÊú∫ÊûÑÔºåÂÖ±Ëã¶‰∫ÜÔºåËá™ÁÑ∂ÁêÜÂ∫îÂêåÁîò„ÄÇ

‰ΩÜÊòØweb3Âàô‰∏ç‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÊú¨ÁØáÂÖ®ÊñáÈÉΩÂú®ËØ¥web3ÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂü∫‰∫éÊÑøÊôØÁöÑ„ÄÅÂÆûÁé∞ÂãüÈõÜ‰∫∫Êâç‰∏éËµÑÈáëÂπ∂ÊäïÂÖ•Áîü‰∫ßÁöÑÁªÑÁªáÂΩ¢ÊÄÅÔºåÈÇ£ÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÂú®Ëøô‰∏™ÁªÑÁªáÂæàÊó©ÊúüÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÊàëÂèÇ‰∏é‰∫ÜËøõÊù•ÔºåÊäïÂÖ•‰∫ÜÊó∂Èó¥‰∏éÈáëÈí±ÔºåÈô™ÁùÄÁªÑÁªá‰∏ÄËµ∑ÂÖ±Ëã¶ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÁªÑÁªáÁöÑÂõûÊä•ÊàëËá™ÁÑ∂‰πüË¶ÅÂêåÁîòÔºåÁªÑÁªáÁöÑÂÜ≥Á≠ñÊàëËá™ÁÑ∂‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ËøõË°åÊäïÁ•®Êù•Ë°®ËææÊàëÁöÑÊÑèÊÑø„ÄÇ Âú®Ë°å‰∏öÂÖ±ËØÜ‰∏≠web3È°πÁõÆÁöÑToken‰∏ÄËà¨Âõ¢ÈòüÂç†‰∏çË∂ÖËøá20%ÔºåÂâ©‰∏ãÁöÑÂ§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÂõûÊä•ÁªôÂèÇ‰∏éÂª∫ËÆæËÄÖÔºåÊÉ≥Ë±°‰∏Ä‰∏ãÂ¶ÇÊûúÊúâ‰∏ÄÂÆ∂web3ÁöÑËÖæËÆØÊääÂÆÉÂ∏ÇÂÄºÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂçäÊï£Âá∫ÂéªÁªô‰∫àÊîØÊåÅËÄÖÔºåËøôÂ∞ÜÊòØÂ§öÂ§ßÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁ¨îË¥¢ÂØåÂÜçÂàÜÈÖç„ÄÇ

title: ÂÜçÂ∫¶Ê∑±Èô∑ÂΩíÈõ∂Ê≠ª‰∫°Ëû∫Êóã‰∏≠ÁöÑ $LUNA 2.0

title: Modern Economic Nonsense ‚Äî Next generation of wealth
body:
*Join BitDAO to earn a $BIT token¬†[here](https://aembassy.io/?mref=11)*

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OKwhrzdqExioznVh3wK9j.jpg?height=173&width=291)


---

Personal wealth is now more accessible than ever. It‚Äôs easier than ever to start investing, and it costs less than ever to do so as well. The internet has made it possible to invest in stock market directly from your desk and get started with little or no money. However, the way we think about wealth has changed too. It used to be about reaching the top of the financial hill and staying there for as long as possible. Today that approach doesn‚Äôt work anymore. Instead of focusing on a single goal, we need to look at new ways to generate income, increase our spending power and build wealth for the future. Wealth is no longer just about having money in reserve for old age; instead it should be used as a tool for enhancing our lives today and tomorrow. The new generation of rich people is those who have flexibility in their careers and can enjoy ample time off from work; they are also those who know how to save money while spending on the things they truly value ‚Äî like education or travel, or cryptocurrency üòâ ‚Äî so they can relax when they retire.

## Create a new financial identity

As you grow your wealth, you‚Äôll want to create a new financial identity. It‚Äôs the idea of having separate accounts for each asset type to help you better understand your wealth. For example, you might want to create an investment account, a savings account, and a retirement account. This way, you can better track your spending and investing behavior. You can also keep your spending under control and avoid unintentionally overspending by only having a single credit card.

In the current great correction of the market, people realized the old method of the investment may no longer work since the higher the inflation with lower the growth potential. You need a new way to generate wealth in a creative yet low-risk way.

## Be proactive in saving for the future

While it‚Äôs OK not to have a specific amount to set aside each month, many people fail to live up to their potential. Remember: the earlier you start saving for retirement, the more you can increase your monthly retirement income. Moreover, the earlier you start saving, the less you risk running out of money during retirement. If you are currently earning a low income, you should put aside as much as you can each month, as high savings rates now can translate into a higher monthly income in retirement. Also, you can find alternative ways to test the new ideas about future finance, including cryptocurrency.

## Invest for the long term and use liquid assets to grow your wealth

When it comes to investing, the earlier the better. This can mean starting young, and investing your spare change. Once you get the hang of it and understand the basic principles, it gets easier. The earlier you start, the better. Especially if you have spare change. Invest in stocks, and crypto such as Bitcoin and Ethereum. With Bitcoin and Ethereum, you can expect a long-term return. A long-term investment strategy is also a good way to grow your wealth over time. You can also use liquid assets to get the biggest bang for your buck. For example, you can use a savings or investment account to withdraw money to cover monthly expenses, then write the transaction off taxes-free. You don‚Äôt want to tie up all your wealth in one investment that might not pay off for years. Also, try to minimize your sending and taking more loans with higher interest payments.

## Don‚Äôt forget about insurance: protect your current and future wealth

If you‚Äôre planning to retire, it helps to understand how much money you‚Äôll need to live comfortably in your retirement years. This is known as your retirement savings goal (RSG). The first step is to calculate your likely annual expenses. This may include: housing payments, food, transportation, insurance, other necessities, and perhaps some travel too. Then, you need to add in your monthly expenses like transportation and health care. Finally, you can add in other important costs like retirement savings, annual vacation, and some discretionary spending money. Once you have a good idea of your current financial situation and your likely expenses in retirement, you can create a retirement savings goal and adjust the goal if necessary. Having a retirement savings goal and an insurance plan will help protect your current wealth and ensure you have enough savings for future generations.

## Bottom line

While it‚Äôs important to celebrate the present, it‚Äôs also important to consider the future. You must never forget where you‚Äôve come from and how far you‚Äôve come. This is how you‚Äôll be able to enjoy the prosperity of the new generation of rich people.¬† 
 

**Reminder:**¬†This article is for educational purposes. I am not your financial advisor. Trust me will risk your investment. Instead, do your own research.

title: Exploring the uncharted jungles of Web3, a personal story.
body:
![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a hexagonal gateway to a sci-fi jungle with neon light streaks](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*MJHc4p_La5DNBt4d0n9TlA.png)

It‚Äôs a messy and confusing place.

So much jargon and technicality that I‚Äôm not surprised why people avoid it or think it‚Äôs a scam. I did too.

Here‚Äôs my story cutting down some vines, turning back a couple of times, and finally set on exploring this jungle of Web3.

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a sci-fi jungle city with neon light streaks, platform and buildings, view no.1](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*_tQzjNb0f4s29gO3XhbDLA.png)

## Part 1: The Awareness

I first heard about blockchain, crypto, and Bitcoin in 2017. It was this revolutionary technology that would change the world or so it seemed.

Blockchain companies were popping up left and right; but it was just whitepapers, initial coin offerings (ICO), and expensive mining rigs ‚Äî no actual implementations.

But I still invited one to present in a forum I organized. I wanted the company I worked for, to not stay stagnant. Well hopefully, the applications of blockchain would spark some ideas, right?

Nope, sadly I later realized that most corporate companies are heavily risk-averse. They preach a lot about innovation and change but continue to act with a legacy and conservative mindset.

I wanted to pursue it further but I didn‚Äôt have much, know where to buy, or even how to mine. And so I left it behind then.

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a sci-fi jungle city with neon light streaks, platform and buildings, view no.2](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*mOL56p0Qq1SGehvb0BIVBg.png)

I focused on learning about more accessible technologies and personal finance as I‚Äôm still a novice compared to my peers.

Crypto was something I still felt was too speculative.

Where do you even spend it? I could count the number of merchants who accepted it in my country with my fingers.

The pandemic hit and well, cash is king.

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a sci-fi jungle city with neon light streaks, platform and buildings, view no.3](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*ShN3qK9T8uyp2lobuAfz-Q.png)

## Part 2: The Impulsive FOMO

2021 arrived and pandemic restrictions became more relaxed.

Bitcoin and Ethereum are huge household names. More crypto companies exist and with much better UI UX, although still not friendly.

But I still could not understand why prices go up or down, I sort of still don‚Äôt.

A part of me regrets that I could have those juicy profits like other people.

Blindly, I decided to invest some. Welp, it was near its *ALL-TIME HIGH*.

Such a terrible decision hahaha. I decided to leave the coins in the exchange and forget about them until I can cover up my losses, or so I thought.

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a window to the sci-fi jungle city](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*CEEZE5OdbLKai3iA8pPPFg.png)

## Part 3: The Enlightenment

I switched jobs in 2022 to pursue a career goal: transforming old traditional companies. Some had been lost due to the pandemic and their inability to keep up with the times.

So I look for new ways of getting revenue. While doing research, NFTs (non-fungible tokens) and their insane prices headlined the news. Since they are just JPEGs, surely I can make money, right?

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a lake with platforms to walk on in the sci-fi jungle city](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*SoKqf_zaa32SrJLlSTs3Iw.png)

Well, that was my rabbit hole to Web3.

I got to know briefly what the culture and community are like, what are corporates doing, how does it work, what new applications are there, what really are NFTs, etc.

DeFi (decentralized finance) was something I was drawn to. I can finally earn something with the dumb coins I invested in. Not much but hey, better than nothing.

I am a believer in this tech/movement‚Äôs larger picture ‚Äî new ways of earning income, financial instruments without a bank account or credit history, communities of things people like or want to accomplish, and many others.

It‚Äôs a whole jungle out there and someone needs help clearing a path.

That may be just you and me. **Welcome to Web3.**


---

Apfel is a product/project /marketer based in SEA and a Web3 newbie. He spends his time‚Äîplaying with his pets, at the gym, lazing in bed, or at his Web2 job he wishes to leave. Check Apfel out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Apfel_eth) or [Lens](https://lensfrens.xyz/apfel.lens).

PS: Apfel is looking for a job in Web3, teehee!

Disclaimer: All images were created using Dall-E.

![DALL¬∑E AI-generated image of a human male exploring the uncharted areas of the sci-fi jungle city](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*RamBGczVRMegm1uNIDSdPg.png)

title: Apple AirPods Pro 2: Design of next-generation premium earbuds leaks with a revised charging case
body:
[52audio](https://www.52audio.com/archives/123351.html)¬†has shared images of the AirPods Pro 2, the long-rumoured replacements for the AirPods Pro that Apple released in 2019. Previously,¬†[52audio](https://www.52audio.com/archives/123351.html)¬†accurately leaked photos of the AirPods 3, as well as providing first looks at the original AirPods Pro three years ago. As far as we can tell, these images are marketing renders, or third-party CAD renders based on a leaked design.

Regardless, the images match the hands-on images leaked by MacRumors in October 2021. As such, the AirPods Pro 2 resemble the AirPods Pro, albeit with minor changes. Specifically, the earbuds retain the stem design of the AirPods Pro but with new sensors to detect when you have removed the earbuds from your ears. Purportedly, the AirPods Pro 2 will support the ALAC and [LC3 codecs](https://www.notebookcheck.net/Apple-could-address-shortcomings-of-the-AirPods-3-AirPods-Pro-and-AirPods-Max-with-future-update.631469.0.html), which should deliver higher audio fidelity while reducing power consumption compared to the AAC and SBC that the original AirPods Pro supports.

**Working For Notebookcheck** 
 Are you a techie who knows how to write? Then join our Team! 
 [Details here](https://www.notebookcheck.net/Jobs.2095.0.html#c92382)

*(Image source: 52audio)*

*(Image source: 52audio)*

**Survey** 
 Join our Support Satisfaction Survey 2022: We want to hear about your experiences! 
 [Participate here](https://www.notebookcheck.net/Survey-Laptop-and-Smartphone-Service-and-Support-Satisfaction-2022.606961.0.html)

Meanwhile, 52audio's leaked images underline that Apple will overhaul the AirPods Pro's charging case with the second-generation model. For one, the website claims that Apple will adopt a USB Type-C charging port, which¬†[9to5Mac](https://9to5mac.com/2022/06/24/airpods-pro-2-case/)¬†doubts is the case. Instead, the latter asserts that all AirPods products will continue to utilise the Lightning connector until after Apple releases the iPhone 15 series in 2025.

As it stands, Apple is expected to announce the AirPods Pro 2 at a launch event alongside the iPhone 14 series and the¬†[Watch Series 8](https://www.notebookcheck.net/Apple-Watch-Series-8-New-render-images-emerge-in-what-could-also-be-the-Apple-Watch-Extreme-Edition.620838.0.html). Currently, Apple is rumoured to have scheduled an event for September 13, during which it could also present the¬†[Watch Extreme Edition](https://www.notebookcheck.net/Leaker-shares-details-about-Apple-September-hardware-event-with-iPhone-14-Pro-Apple-Watch-Extreme-Edition-and-Apple-M2-showcase.620100.0.html).

title: Ownership - cryptocurrency market vs stock market
body:
## The most fundamental difference is what you buy.

Stocks represent a percentage of ownership (or capital) in a company.  When you buy stocks on the stock exchange, you own the portion of the traded company.  This naturally gives you some rights, such as voting rights.

On the other hand, when you buy a cryptocurrency, you only own the token and the value of the digital asset.  It will not give you the property rights to the crypto coin making company.  However, there are thousands of crypto coins, each designed to meet a specific need - some, such as Bitcoin, are now a digital commodity, as is gold, many others are designed to be used in specific operations.

It is recommended that you do a basic layer of research to understand the ecosystem before choosing the coins you want to invest in.

### Value - digital currencies vs.  stock market shares

In stocks, the value is based on the physical firm, and the returns or value of the stocks depend on the performance and development of the company whose stocks you own.  The share price rises and falls based on forecasts for the company's future success.

Cryptocurrency is not backed by any hard assets as, as a digital asset, its value depends on supply and demand as well as market sentiment.

title: Luna 2.0 Re-Enters into Going-to-Zero Death Spiral
body:
Market chose Luna as sandbox project to envision Hayek‚Äôs decentralised stablecoin assumption and the concept of algorithmic stablecoin. While Luna‚Äôs success in the last bear market and most of the bull market is in line with our expectation for the algorithmic stablecoin sandbox project in a stable environment, its rapid going to zero exposes serious system framework vulnerability which can‚Äôt defend against malicious market shorting. Luna team promptly shuted down Luna, Luna 2.0 or 3.0, a new going-to zero game, was quickly launched by Luna team to undertake traffic and, undboubtedly, to make up for its absence or ‚Äúloss‚Äù during this shoring round. 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/K99dZXEhE5TtcBJWDOzGR.png?height=787&width=1400)

Previously Luna had served as a store of value that underpinned algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD‚Äôs peg to the U.S. dollar. If TerraUSD is traded higher than $1, traders could exchange it for Luna. Luna would be destroyed in the process while TerraUSD would be created, until the new supply of Luna eventually pushed the exchange rate back to parity. This process also worked in reverse, when TerraUSD is traded below $1.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xdE9ouj2sivPW4uBhz6IQ.png?height=696&width=1372)

Luna is attractive because it builds a decentralized stablecoin system which needn‚Äôt rely on fiat currency as a reserve to maintain its peg, extinguishing it from the existing stablecoin Tether. Luna didn‚Äôt just enjoy support from retail crypto investors, even prominent professionals such as Real Vision CEO Raoul Pau promoted the Terra/Luna pair created by Do Kwon. Ex‚ÄìGoldman Sachs banker and CEO of Galaxy Digital Partners Mike Novogratz famously tattooed his support for Luna on his arm.

Luna‚Äôs rapid crash severely damaged confidence in TerraUSD/Luna algo stablecoin system, and proved the existing model‚Äôs unability to realize Hayek‚Äôs decentralized stablecoin assumption. Luna crash had such an extensive impact that it drove the broader market to decouple itself from its rally in tech stock, and renewed speculation around a regulatory crackdown on stablecoins.

Not only was the Luna team completely unaware of the serious vulnerability in the TerraUSD/luna system before the crash, they also failed to take timely and effective counter measures during it. Although the linked exchange rate system of TerraUSD/luna was abandoned later, the crazy over-issue of Luna made it impossible for any one to restore Luna price and its downward trend.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/mp9eI8X5RiwfNAA50ecem.png?height=423&width=752)

After a 99% price plunge, Luna is no longer able nor needed to protect the algo stablecoin UST‚Äô parity to the U.S. dollar, the coin has lost its entire raison d‚Äô√™tre as its market price.

To a certain extent, Luna 2.0 is a new game released by Do Kwon so as to undertake traffic and cover its own losses. Lacking a new reliable model nor decentralized value, Luna 2.0 loses support from its former institutional supporters and maintains the status quo by Do Kwon‚Äôs pledge of a 7% reward.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/k5I0CZ7kcnxI_uSZYoCnE.png?height=675&width=1200)

A test item from Do Kown‚Äôs hasty decision, Luna 2.0 was produced from a hard fork in the protocol collectively approved by the community through a majority vote in mid May, similar to the 2016 hard fork that created Ethereum and Ethereum Classic. Luna 2.0 follows Luna‚Äôs unpegged model and doesn‚Äôt have a nice new trustworthy anchor relationship with stablecoins.

The utility of Luna 2.0 token is in doubt as the faith in its predecessor had already been obliterated. Binance is listing Luna 2.0 on its¬†[Innovation Zone](https://www.binance.com/en/support/announcement/d044a6742e484b77a170111460b0eed3?ref=AZTKZ9XS&utm_source=BinanceTwitter&utm_medium=GlobalSocial&utm_campaign=GlobalSocial)¬†for particularly risky investments.

According to CoinMarketCap, Luna 2.0 launched at a debut price of $17.80 on May 28th. After tanking 80% and being listed by exchanges listed Luna, investors rushed back to support it and pumped Luna 2.0‚Äôs price from $6.15 to a peak of $11.97 hours before its listing on Binance. Binance¬†[listed](https://www.binance.com/en/support/announcement/d044a6742e484b77a170111460b0eed3)¬†Luna 2.0 at 2:00 a.m. Eastern on May 31st . But Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao¬†[claimed](https://twitter.com/cz_binance/status/1530572426152759297)¬†on Twitter that the exchange needed more time to prepare for Luna 2.0‚Äôs airdrop and listing due to its ‚Äúlarge userbase.‚Äù Binance starts a year-long process to convert user holdings of Luna and TerraUSD (the two cryptocurrencies launched by Do Kwon‚Äôs Terraform Labs) into Luna 2.0 by airdropping the replacement coins into affected user wallets, which will make Luna 2.0 price more volatile.

Binance was an early investor in Terraform Labs, the creator of the Luna and UST coins. To avoid unnecessary risks, Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao claimed that the exchange led a $32 million funding round in 2018, it invested only $3 million in Terra and was not involved in later funding rounds.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/30YVkiqt3ysR9A8jDm9vh.png?height=630&width=1200)

The development of Luna 2.0 so far has been counterproductive to Do Kwon‚Äôs original envision. When Terraform Labs CEO airdropped deposits of its new token Luna 2.0 into users‚Äô virtual wallets, holders rushed for the exits in an attempt to salvage what little they still could from their original investment. The value of Luna 2.0¬†[promptly plunged](https://cryptoslate.com/luna-2-0-hits-30-then-drops-80-in-first-day-of-trading/)¬†80% to around $5. No one is willing to hold Luna any more, they know Do Kwon‚Äôs arrogance and hasty decisions will send Luna 2.0 to fall through. Luna‚Äôs propose of sending millions or even billions of Luna into a virtual black hole would be little more than a drop in the bucket for a coin that ballooned to a supply of over 6.5 trillion in the immediate aftermath of TerraUSD losing its peg. Though Luna is seemingly fighting to the last ditch, no one forgets the crash wiped out roughly $60 billion in market capitalization last month. So whether it‚Äôs a joke or a fact, we have to be ready for Luna 2.0 going to zero, and get ready for Luna 3.

**4 Billion DAO:**
4 Billion DAO is a DAO that exists for EOS community justice.
4 Billion DAO From the community, Back to the community, For the community.

body:
ÊàëËÆ∞ÂæóÂú®ÂéªÂπ¥Âπ¥Â∫ïÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂú∫È•≠Â±Ä‰∏äÔºåÁªìËØÜ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰ΩçÁªèÂéÜÂ§öÊ¨°Â∏ÇÂú∫ÁÜäÁâõÁöÑÊúãÂèã„ÄÇ‰ªñËØ¥ËøôËΩÆÁâõÂ∏ÇËÆ©‰ªñÁúãÈÄöÈÄè‰∫ÜÔºåÊ¥ªÊòéÁôΩ‰∫Ü„ÄÇÁªôÊàë‰ª¨Áïô‰∏ãÂØπÂ∏ÇÂú∫Ëµ∞ÁÜäÁöÑÂÆöËÆ∫ÂêéÔºåË∂ÅÁùÄÁñ´ÊÉÖÁöÑÁºìËß£ÔºåÂçèË∞ÉÂ•ΩÂá∫Â¢É‰∫ãÂÆú‰æøÊãçÊãçÂ±ÅËÇ°ÂéªÂë®Ê∏∏‰∏ñÁïå‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

# Block.oneÂßãÁªàÂ∞ÜEOSÈ°πÁõÆ‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏ÄÁßçÂúàÈí±ÊâãÊÆµ

ÊàëËÆ§‰∏∫EOS‰ªéÁôΩÁöÆ‰π¶‰ΩúËÄÖDaniel LarimerÊâÄÊèèËø∞ÁöÑÂå∫ÂùóÈìæ2.0ËΩ¨ÂêëÊóÅÊ∞èÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÊòØEOSÂâçÁÆ°ÊéßÊñπBlock.oneÈ´òÂ±ÇÂØπÂå∫ÂùóÈìæÈ°πÁõÆÊìç‰Ωú‰∏éËÆ§ËØÜ„ÄÇBlock.oneÂÜÖÈÉ®È´òÂ±ÇÂØπEOSÁöÑÁúãÊ≥ïÂÆûÈôÖÂ∫îËØ•‰∏é‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂØπÂ§ñÂÆ£‰º†Êà™ÁÑ∂Áõ∏Âèç„ÄÇ
